text: Stress from unusually warm ocean water heated by man-made climate change and the natural El Ni√±o climate pattern caused the die-off.
The good news, scientists said, was that central and southern sections of the reef fared far better, with "only" 6% and 1% of the coral dead, respectively.
When water temperatures become too high, coral becomes stressed and expels the algae, which leave the coral a bleached white color.

start: Mass coral bleaching is a new phenomenon and was never observed before the 1980s as global warming ramped up.

text: But looking to the future, mass coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef will likely be an annual phenomenon within a decade, Torda said.
